newsitem.title: USA: Arkansas water/sewer bill advances in state Senate.
newsitem.headline: Arkansas water/sewer bill advances in state Senate.

text.p: A bill that would merge Arkansas' water and sewer programs and authorize up to $300 million of combined bonding authority passed out of a key state senate committee Tuesday, a Arkansas official said Wednesday.
According to Randy Young, executive director of the Arkansas Soil and Water Conservation Commission, the bill would authorize the commission to issue up to $300 million of general obligation bonds.
Issuance would be limited to $60 million per fiscal biennium, unless the state's general assembly granted approval.
The soil and water commission currently administers both programs, Young said.
The first is called the Water Resources General Obligation Bond Development program. The second is the Arkansas Waste and Pollution Abatement General Obligation Bond program.

"We proposed last session to merge them so we would have common regulations (and) application procedures," Young said, adding that occasionally a municipality will want to borrow for both water and waste water purposes. If the senate bill is approved, "we could do it with one financing," he said.
The bill passed out of the Senate's Agriculture and Economic Development Committee on Tuesday.
It proceeds to the Senate floor for a vote. If the bill receives approval from both the state Senate and House of Representatives, it will go to Governor Mike Huckabee for signing.
The bill would then go before voters in the 1998 general election, Young said.
Meanwhile, a House bill authorizing up to $12.025 million of additional bonding authority for the soil and water commission passed the state assembly's joint budget committee last week.
If that bill passes the legislature and is signed by Governor Huckabee, it would clear the way for the commission to issue $15 million in bonds for projects on deck in the current biennium.
Approval for the additional authority is necessary because when voters approved $100 million of water bonding authority back in 1985, the measure limited issuance to $15 million a biennium.

The $12 million is needed to augment the $2 million to $3 million of approved bonding authority remaining for the current biennium, which concludes June 30, Young said. Young added that the commission has already received additional bonding authority for this biennium.

In addition, the House bill would authorize issuance of up to $24.7 million during the next biennium, which runs from July 1, 1997 to June 30, 1999. The $24.7 million would finish off the remainder of the 1985 $100 million of authorization, Young said.
